Former JHU Prof Lane Dies
Frederic C. Lane, profesor
emeritus of history at Hopkins,
died on Saturday, October 20 at
his home in Westminster,
Massachusetts, after a long illness. He was 83.
There will be no funeral service. The family will hold a
memorial service later in
November at their home in
Massachusetts.
A specialist in the history of
Venice, the Italian Renaissance
and European Economy, Lane
servd on the faculty of Johns
Hopkins for 38 years, from
1928 to 1966. Upon his retirement in the spring of 1966, he
was named professor emeritus
by the University.
In addition to Lane's
teaching and research, he en-

joyed a variety of professional
honors and positions. He was
editor of the Journal of
Economic History (1943-1951);
historian of the U.S. Maritime
Commission (1946-47); and
assistant director of the division
of social sciences at the
Rockefeller Foundation in
Europe (1951-54).
He also served as president of
the American Historical
Association (1965), the Society
for Italian Historical Studies
(1962), and the Economic
History Association (1956).
In 1980, he was awarded the
Galileo Galilei Prize of the
.Italian Rotary Clubs (the
Italian "Nobel") which was
presented to him in ceremonies
held at the University of Pisa in

Italy. This prestigious award is
presented annually to a foreign
scholar whose work has furthered understanding and
recognition of Italy.
Lane is the author of
numerous books, articles and
reviews ranging from the
definition of medieval shipping
tonnages to the assessment of
the economic consequences of
organized violence. His most
notable books include Venetian
Ships and Shipbuilders of the
Renaissance (1934); Andrea
Barbarigo, Merchant of
Venice, 1418-1449 (1944);
"Shipsfor Victory: A History
ofShipbuilding Under the U.S.
Maritime Commission (1951);
and Venice, A Maritime
Republic (1973).

Insecurity
Over the past two weeks, there has been
a significant increase in the number of crimes
against person on the Johns Hopkins
Homewood campus and in surrounding
areas. We, as students and as citizens, are
justifiably concerned about this situation. It
seems there is little we can do, however, to
rectify the problem.
Members of the Homewood community
should beable to rely upon the protection
and support activities of the campus security force. Unfortunately, the services provided by this organization are often inadequate
and, when present, seem dangerously slow.
We feel this may be attributed to a severe
security manpower shortage and, in light of
current events, this dilemma must be addressed immediately.
Not only do we demand that the security
force be strengthened in order to better protect the campus, but also that its activities
be extended to provide adequate security to
those students living off campus. This is not
an unreasonable nor an inappropriate request. The vast majority of Hopkins students
reside off campus and the library shuttle service, while useful, is an incomplete safety

provision.
We would not suggest that security officers be stationed at every corner in Charles
Village or in Hampden. Rather, we insist
that the University provide the means to improve the existing system. More security personnel should be hired. Regular foot and
automobile patrols should be implemented
and students informed of their schedule. Better lighting equipment should be installed at
Homewood, especially along well-travelled
paths. Campus emergency phones and a foot
escort service originating at the library, suggested by the Student Life committee of the
Student Council, are likewise appropriate
measures.
Until the Johns Hopkins University
recognizes that a safety deficit exists and
begins to take effective action, we urge all
students to exercise caution, especially in the
evening. Avoid taking chances which might
endanger your well-being, such as walking
home alone at 2:00 a.m. from the Hut or a
weekend party. Be aware that you are living in a city which has one of the highest per
capita crime rates in the country.

obscurity to playoff contention.

offensive skill positions. John

will be sorely missed.

Former JHU Prof Lane Dies
Frederic C. Lane, profesor
emeritus of history at Hopkins,
died on Saturday, October 20 at
his home in Westminster,
Massachusetts, after a long illness. He was 83.
There will be no funeral service. The family will hold a
memorial service later in
November at their home in
Massachusetts.
A specialist in the history of
Venice, the Italian Renaissance
and European Economy, Lane
servd on the faculty of Johns
Hopkins for 38 years, from
1928 to 1966. Upon his retirement in the spring of 1966, he
was named professor emeritus
by the University.
In addition to Lane's
teaching and research, he en-

joyed a variety of professional
honors and positions. He was
editor of the Journal of
Economic History (1943-1951);
historian of the U.S. Maritime
Commission (1946-47); and
assistant director of the division
of social sciences at the
Rockefeller Foundation in
Europe (1951-54).
He also served as president of
the American Historical
Association (1965), the Society
for Italian Historical Studies
(1962), and the Economic
History Association (1956).
In 1980, he was awarded the
Galileo Galilei Prize of the
.Italian Rotary Clubs (the
Italian "Nobel") which was
presented to him in ceremonies
held at the University of Pisa in

Italy. This prestigious award is
presented annually to a foreign
scholar whose work has furthered understanding and
recognition of Italy.
Lane is the author of
numerous books, articles and
reviews ranging from the
definition of medieval shipping
tonnages to the assessment of
the economic consequences of
organized violence. His most
notable books include Venetian
Ships and Shipbuilders of the
Renaissance (1934); Andrea
Barbarigo, Merchant of
Venice, 1418-1449 (1944);
"Shipsfor Victory: A History
ofShipbuilding Under the U.S.
Maritime Commission (1951);
and Venice, A Maritime
Republic (1973).
